conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time.
The area under the acceleration-time graph gives the change in velocity.
The object starts from rest, so the initial velocity is 0.
From t=0 to t=1 s, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s², and velocity increases linearly.
Change in velocity from t=0 to t=1 s is 2 m/s.
At t=1 s, velocity is 2 m/s.
From t=1 to t=2 s, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
Change in velocity from t=1 to t=2 s is 1 m/s.
At t=2 s, velocity is 3 m/s.
From t=2 to t=3 s, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
Change in velocity from t=2 to t=3 s is -1 m/s.
At t=3 s, velocity is 2 m/s.
From t=3 to t=4 s, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s², and velocity decreases linearly.
Change in velocity from t=3 to t=4 s is -2 m/s.
At t=4 s, velocity is 0 m/s.
The maximum velocity occurs at t=2 s, where the velocity is 3 m/s.
